0.body:
How to use Gmail with Google Apps
[image: Google]

Hi Nisarg

Work smarter with Gmail and Google Apps

[image: Calendar]
Manage Calendar meetings

Google Calendar <https://www.google.com/calendar> makes scheduling meetings
easy with shared calendars. You’ll get invites and reminders and can even
join a scheduled video meeting right from your inbox.
[image: Send Large files]
Use Drive to send large files

Send huge files in Gmail
<https://support.google.com/mail/answer/2480713?hl=en&utm_source=gmailwelcomeemail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=gmailwelcome>
(up to 5TB) using Google Drive <https://drive.google.com/>. Plus, files
stored in Drive stay up-to-date automatically so everyone has the most
recent version and can access them from anywhere.
[image: Collaborate]
Collaborate on documents

Get email alerts when someone comments on your shared document in Docs
<https://docs.google.com/document/>, Sheets
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/> and Slides
<https://docs.google.com/presentation>. To respond to the comment, just
reply to the email.
[image: Forms]
Get quick answers with Forms

Send Google Forms <https://docs.google.com/forms> via email. Recipients can
complete forms and respond right from their inbox.


[image: Gmail icon] Happy emailing,
The Gmail Team
© 2016 Google Inc. 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

1.body:
The best of Gmail, wherever you are
[image: Google]
[image: Nexus 4 with Gmail]

Hi Nisarg


Get the official Gmail app

The best features of Gmail are only available on your phone and tablet with
the official Gmail app. Download the app or go to gmail.com
<https://www.gmail.com/> on your computer or mobile device to get started.

[image: Google Play]
<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.gm>  [image:
App Store] <https://itunes.apple.com/en/app/gmail/id422689480?mt=8>


[image: Gmail icon] Happy emailing,
The Gmail Team
© 2016 Google Inc. 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

2.body:
Tips for using your new inbox
[image: Google]

Hi Nisarg

Welcome to your Gmail inbox

[image: Storage]
Save everything

With tons of storage space, you’ll never need to delete an email. Just keep
everything and easily find it later.
[image: Search]
Find emails fast

With the power of Google Search right in your inbox, you can quickly find
the important emails you need with suggestions based on your emails, past
searches and contacts.
[image: Inbox]
Arrange your inbox to fit your work style

Choose to see *unread*, *starred* or *important* messages at the top of
your inbox or try Priority Inbox
<https://support.google.com/mail/answer/186531?hl=en&utm_source=gmailwelcomeemail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=gmailwelcome>,
which combines all of these. Go to the Inbox tab in Gmail settings to make
changes <https://mail.google.com/mail/#settings/inbox>.
[image: Video meetings]
Send messages and hold video meetings from your inbox

Chat with contacts and start video meetings with up to 15 people in Google+
Hangouts
<https://www.google.com/enterprise/apps/business/products.html?hl=en&utm_source=gmailwelcomeemail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=gmailwelcome#hangouts>
.
[image: Contacts]
Bring your contacts into Gmail

You can import your contacts
<https://support.google.com/a/answer/14024?hl=en&topic=3056079&utm_source=gmailwelcomeemail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=gmailwelcome>
from other webmail to make the transition to Gmail easier. Learn how
<https://support.google.com/a/answer/14024?hl=en&topic=3056079&utm_source=gmailwelcomeemail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=gmailwelcome>


[image: Gmail icon] Happy emailing,
The Gmail Team
© 2016 Google Inc. 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

8.body:
This is really nice!!  

We have a pinterest board already for the office interiors, maybe I can share it with you. 

C


> On Jun 24, 2016, at 11:04 AM, Andres Richner <andres@intelligaia.com> wrote:
> 
> Hi all,
> 
> Thank you to all who participated in the Friday Office Brainstorm (Nisarg, Shaline, and Jonathan). We should try to have these every Friday morning to wake up our brains for the last push of the week.
> 
> Sandeep, Rajiv, Cheena, and rest of the NC team... we took 25 minutes this morning to brainstorm "What should we put on our office walls?". The first 10-15 minutes we jotted down ideas without saying NO to anything, then the last 10 minutes we listed the set of "problems" that our ideas seem to address. The list of "problems" can serve as our project goals, and from there we can work out a strategy.
> 
> The exercise was meant to show how brainstorms should be quick to be fruitful. It was also meant to provide us with an initial set of actionable goals to start making the office come alive. 
> 
> Best,
> 
> Andrés A. Richner
> Senior UX Strategist / Designer - Intelligaia (RTP)
> <IMG_2143.JPG><IMG_2144.JPG>

Good morning to all,

I hope you all had a nice weekend and are able to start fresh today. I know
that for myself, today will be intense. I have an important meeting at
Cisco around 11am. For this reason, I will not be coming to The Frontier in
the morning. I will try to make my way to our office right after that
meeting, at which point I'll be joining a webex tutorial for another hour.

I expect to be able to be around more as the week progresses, but just
wanted to give everyone a heads up.

Best,

Andrés A. Richner

Hi all,

Today I'll be at Frontier in the AM. I want to connect with Shirley in
person briefly, so I'll probably swing around Cisco during the early
afternoon.

Tomorrow Thursday I have a late morning meeting at Cisco, so I'll be over
there. Jonathan is also part of that meeting, so interns should check about
getting into Frontier office. After that meeting is over, I have to work
from home in the afternoon. My dog-walker had an unexpected death in the
family, so she has a funeral to go to.

On Friday, I'm not sure yet how I'll divide my time, but I have my dog's
last physical therapy appointment at 4pm, so I'll be offline a little
before that.

My calendar is updated to reflect meetings and moments I might not be
available.

Hope everyone stays cool and dry in this rainy, hot week.

Andrés A. Richner
Senior UX Strategist / Designer - Intelligaia (RTP)

62.body:
Meeting with Sunil 7/11

Below are the meeting points from the meeting today. Andres will provide next steps and design direction based on this feedback. 

1. Save for Later Button
• What was the idea behind the wording?
• It can also say "Download Now" or "Add to Wishlist"
• Check out Apple Store

2. Add Bundle Option
• It's in sales kit
• Similar to apple store (you can create a game bundle)
• Group app together

3. Add Categories 
• Need innovative icons and improved visual communication
• Think of "branding" for the categories
• Make it rich and sleek
• Show what is popular within each category
• Each category will have its own homepage

4. Instead of "Trending", maybe say "Most Featured App"?

5. Make each row (latest releases, trends, etc.) visually different

6. Images shapes should all be the same (some are now rectangular and others square)

7. Look into Sales Connect and incorporate some of the features/components that are applicable... for example:
• # of times it is downloaded
• # of times viewed
• # of time shared
• Rating
• Who developed it

8. Personas (there are two)
• Developers (those who build the apps)
• End user/customers (those who search, download, and use the apps)

-S





--

88.body:
Hi Team, 
Please find the details of meeting,

Meeting Type : Internal
Meeting Link: https://cisco.webex.com/ciscosales/lsr.php?RCID=58fb8dff69e448cdacf7f1c62eb98ae1
Meeting Password:   6sZfZMRY 

Meeting Notes:

1. The two options for home page in gray scale is on right track.However, we can try to come up with more options based on exploration, if time permits. But until we get the confirmation from client based on those two approaches, we can hold off working on homepage.

2. The proposed approach for client meeting is to showcase the "sample mock up" which is aimed at laying down the core components covering one of the flow in reference to CJMs. This will help client to envisage the look & feel of the app store. At the same time, the grayscale wireframes having different options will help us know which approach client is keen to go on. This will help team to build designs based on their selected/accepted approach.

3. There need to be  a point where client is validating our requirement gathering which we have initiated in the form of User stories "globally" and specific based on page wise  (Homepage, App Listing Page, App detail page etc) having components.

4. Upon Validating the approach and the scope items they (client) want to touch base first (prioritizing the items), we can plan them in definite sprint cycles.

Next Steps:

1. Nihal to update the visuals created for tiles based on feedback shared by Andres (mainly with the imagery or banners which is contextual to the app store)

2.  More options for App Listing and App Detail page so that we can take them to selection of different options from client

3. Design high level mocks as sample mock up to showcase the components corresponding to the CJMs (One of the flow)

4. Style Guide is pending and need to get initiated ASAP. I would recommend, if Jonathan can take this further from next week.

5. Break the user stories and plug the validated user stories into the template. Currently we have high level user stories for End User only. We need to explore the opportunity for "Developer" as persona in the App Center.

Please add any other pointer which I may have missed,
Thanks
Dev




--

93.body:
Notes from Meeting with Sinna & Phani on 7/15

1. Andres gave a walkthrough of the latest grayscale wireframes

2. Are we considering using 100% width? If not, is there a reason?

3. What stands out in the current design that SHOULD be done differently?
• Images are huge
• There are not a lot of apps
• Categories
• First page is too focused on marketing
• There is a movement away from carousels
• filtering at this stage might not be needed given the amount of apps
• Doesn't communicate the value of the apps


4. The persona's who are going to use this are hard core techies
• They are not going into the site to play
• They will visit the site to make sure the app is working
• Might not expand past this persona - 80% of the time it will be techies
• App store applies to many personas, but Cisco app center, won't... just something to keep in mind
• What technical information can we show that applies to the persona
• As a techie, I want to see what people are succeeding with and what challenges are they having with the app

5. Amazon has a system of splitting the information between what works and what doesn't


6. Will the traditional way of showing Related Apps work for this persona? It might not, so think if there should be a different approach.
• Business might need to mature before we get data to support Related Apps• Related apps might be different for different apps



7. Categories Wireframe
• On what basis will apps surface out to a particular page?
• How are the categories prioritized?
• By most recent - latest post

Main Conclusions For UX Team
• Consider using 100%
• Images that appeal to techies
• Show related apps will be helpful (But think in what context and how)
• Show app Challenges vs Successes (so the persona is aware of what they need to change in their app and what is working well)
• Don't forget that Sunil also wants us to think about how Sales Connect features can be implemented into Cisco App Center

Next Steps
• Two screens of high fidelity mock-ups for Sinna to show Ram next week (Landing page and App page)
• Sinna needs mock-ups by Tuesday
• Send update on progress on Monday




--

Hi Team,


Landing Page and Detail Page(End User Flow)
We started working on UI for Homepage and App detail page. We worked around it as per the end user view. As we need inputs for developer’s view from the team to initiate visuals for it.


Logic:
We have chosen the concept which Andres liked the most. When user comes to the landing page he looks apps and bundled kits at first glance. As he clicks one of the apps, the tile expands and transforms into pop-up showcasing more information and related content in it.
Link:
http://cisco.projecthost.us/UI_Template/index3.php?project_id=428&module_id=119&page=7587

Moodboard
I worked on the moldboard for responsive category section. Went through some best practices and jotted down the pointers with screenshot.

Please find the below link:
https://3.basecamp.com/3207078/buckets/1088069/uploads/172430006

Wireframes file is uploaded in Git-hub but UI file is having some conflict with the Git-hub. I will try to fix it as soon as possible.

Hi Team,

Notes from Andres:


Landing Page (Concept 03)
• Search in the header
• Banner with split view (No caraousal)
• New App
• Featured App
• App of the week
• New style of Browsing content
• Square illustrations for app
• Mouse Hover
• Star rating system


Detail Page (Concept 01 + Concept 03)
• Square icon with details
• Download button
• Segments tabs for Details, Reviews, Support and API info
• Think about how to show related apps


We worked according to the notes sent by Andres.
Please find the specifications below:
Worked on the landing page as per the meeting recording sent by Andres. Tried to implement simple visual components to the wireframes sent by J. UI is based on bootstrap gird as it will be easier to make it responsive in future. Tried to do full justice to the top banner by applying best fit images in it. Used app icon styling for individual applications. 
Logic:
When user hovers a tile, it gets a bit big and on click user is directed to it’s detail page.
Detail page has introductory info and segments tabs for details, reviews, support and API info.
Related apps
One thing to notice that I have shown the related apps in the bottom itself because there are four segments tabs and we can not populate it more with related apps. So I kept it there in the bottom and it’s one of my rationale thoughts.

113.body:
Thank you to Jonathan and Nihal for the tag team work... which will continue today.

Jonathan, below I'm posting how to move Nihal's designs even further.

1. Realism
Nihal has placed some nice-looking placeholders. However, something that our stakeholders will definitely pick up on is the use of images that are out of context (for example, the New app is a Buzz Aldrin app, but... that wouldn't be in Cisco App Center). So, my first direction is for something that's a bit tricky but I think important. Let's make sure that, even if we make new illustrations for certain things (like the banner), that it's more in line with what is currently in or will be featured in the Cisco App Center.

2. Landing Page
I think the only other states to show of the Landing Page are filtered states using our tabbed menu. I'm proposing:

a. show landing page filtered for "Graphical Interface"
b. show landing page ordered by "Popularity"

Oh, yeah, a little comment about those 3 tabs. Should we not say "Display by:" first, and then the tabs would be: Category, Latest Release, Popularity? 

3. App Details Page
I'm most interested in showing them:
a. Reviews tab
b. Support tab

Although I had discussed with Sinna an alternative (thumb up/down) way to do reviews, Jonathan and I discussed that, by having a Support section where users can report bugs and suggestions, we can then keep the more common star-rating system while giving users more insight into what works and what doesn't in the app. 



--

119.body:
Hi team,

Jonathan did further work yesterday the 19th, based on Nihal's design. 


• We realized that the tiles on the landing page need to be wider until the app center grows and has many more apps. We can keep the smaller tiles in the "back burner" and show client how they can switch to those once the app center grows in number of apps.
• Jonathan came up with a dark UI version for the App Details page that looks really slick. I think we should make further illustrations of the App Details page with this dark UI.
• We also explored a couple of mobile concepts, but we should probably also include Nihal's and compare before making any decisions on those.
• Oh, and I provided J with more realistic images to use across the board.

What could Nihal take up "tonight"?


• I think we should get to illustrating what the other tabs in App Details would contain, especially Reviews and Support.*
• After that, anything that you think could complement the current designs is fine, including maybe adding back showing the search functionality you had in the grayscale wireframes.

I think that Jonathan and Nihal's tag team work has been yielding some really awesome results.

*What is the Support tab?



We are basing this concept on a feature in some apps on the Chromestore. It's basically a way for users of an app to message the developer(s) of the app about problems / suggestions / bugs. It helps to provide info in addition to the reviews for other potential users, since reviews can sometimes be too vague or subjective.





--

122.body:
Hi Team,


We worked according to the requirements posted by Andres. 
Please find the specifications below:


Reviews Page Logic
I wanted to make it more user specific so when user comes to this segment he can see individual comments. User can see other users comments about the product.
In each user review, there is description and ratings. To add more value shown some words like ‘Excellent’ and ‘4 out of 5 stars’ for the reviews section.
Also user can see sum of ratings on the right and it is the most important part as it gives a very clear view of the product experience.
To give user more power I have given an ability for sorting the reviews as well. User can also add reviews by clicking ‘Write a Review’ button. A pop-up comes up and user can fill it in.


Support Page Logic
User can see different kinds of posts by other people regarding app problems, suggestions and questions as well.
Each post contains subject and description and date of creation. Also user can click on ‘Tell the Developer’ to post his concerns accordingly.


Some pointers for J.
• I can see a lot of good components coming out of Jonathan’s plate. I like the styling and visual treatment. But I am concerned about the width which is taken by J. I did not see any grid structure in the artboards for the dimensions. J can you please use some full width grid to align all the components. Or specify the dimensions so that our components do not fall off.
• I always love the responsive part. J did full justice to the responsive view but I see some fonts are very large and some are very small. Can you please look into this.
• Also if you can use iPhone grid for mobile platform, it will be awesome.
• Detail pages have smaller tiles. I am not sure about this logic.


Nucleux:
http://cisco.projecthost.us/UI_Template/index3.php?project_id=428&module_id=119&page=7610

Files are uploaded in Git-hub.


Thanks,
Nihal Ahluwalia

124.body:
Thanks Team for great collaboration,

After seeing the designs, I was thinking that, what is the value add for an app to success, is it the review page or the app detail page. As a user I would need to gauge the app based on 'reviews' so I think that is the core area where we may need to think on what all elements that brings out more value addition for an app user. That is the decision maker page for user.

I see quick glance of number of good reviews in the design but what should be the default view for review page of an app that should bind the user to read more, I think the maximum count of success with particular app which is essentially the good reviews by other users.

Andres, these are my thoughts right now, and I can see more opportunity in the review page specifically.

Thanks
Dev

135.body:
Hi team,

I was checking the initial plan which was dedicated for the Cisco App Center, currently we are at 3rd week and let's push on the activities which are mandate for 5D process. Let me retrospect some, 

D1: Discover - We have covered discover phase well.

D2: Define : the pending items are
•   Style guide
• Decomposing user stories 
 Additionally, we have created grayscale wire frames having different approaches the intent of having multiple approaches to get the confirmation on one of the approach which goes ahead in design

D3: Design
We are currently designing one of the options to show client how the grayscale wireframes will look in colors.

IMO, we should have already got feedback from client (Sinna) & Rajiv already, lets  incorporate that within the design paradigms and seek feedback and confirmation.

For me, I need to have confirmed requirements/approaches from client, so that User stories can be decomposed and I can plan them in production sprints.

Let's discuss on this more during our scheduled meeting.


Thanks
Dev

137.body:
Hi Team,

Today we worked on the standardization for UI components.
Below are the specifications:
1. Went through the full width best practices and decided to take fluid grid structure which will be helpful to stream lines our components.
2. Established library/style sheet for typography. We are using only four fonts for the whole application.
3. Made colour swatches for UI components. We have four colours only to work with.
4. Refined components like header and banner.
5. Used rule of thirds and fluid grid

Mock-ups
1. So far we tried to achieve landing page two approaches. One with bigger tiles as liked by Andres. According to my instinct I also showed smaller versions of tiles.
2. Also we showed responsive view for the landing page.

I will be sharing the in progress style sheet and I am working on the further pages.

Nucleux:
http://cisco.projecthost.us/UI_Template/index3.php?project_id=428&module_id=119&page=7631

Thanks,
Nihal ahluwalia

141.body:
Hi Andres,

Sinna forwarded an e-mail and meeting recording from a meeting with the ACI App Center folks where they discuss their requirements for the landing page. The idea would be to review the recording and identify what is missing in our current design. The discussion they have is based on the current site and not our designs.

I will let you direct the design team with next steps. Please discuss with designers and then you and I can discuss when we can share the next iteration with these ideas incorporated. 

Key callouts for the landing page shared by "Lucy":

1. In the header display the following links
• “Categories” – When user clicks on this, it will display a drop down menu of the categories.  Selecting a menu item will bring the user to the app listing page for the selected category.“Join as a Developer” –   The intent is to allow the user to register for a developer account. 
• NOTE:  Per existing business rules, ONLY users with a CCO profile designated as a partner.In essence this behaves exactly like the current “Register” link in the up right hand drop down
• “DevNet” – When the user clicks on this, it will open up a new window to DevNet

2. The carousel  currently rotates between 2 sections.  The ask is to have it rotate between 3:
• First:  Introducing to the Cisco App Center (button will  still be  ‘Browse apps’)
• Second:  Application Centric Infrastructure  (button will open up a new window to an ACI page)
• Third:  Developer Ecosystem – (button action TBD)

3. Featured apps section (leave as is)

4. Add in a section that lists the categories as tiles – Clicking on a category will bring the user to the app listing page for the category

5. Add in a section for “News and more”
• This section will be broken up into 3 columns (or tiles) the content of which will be dictated by the BU

6. Developer onboarding section (leave as is)

7. Footer section (leave as is)

Recording: https://cisco.webex.com/ciscosales/lsr.php?RCID=a45e19148cfa48d8bbedbe8df504d1fb
Recording password: mGcmk3ZQ

Thanks!
-S



--

145.body:
Hi Shirley,

This is part of why we need a discussion with the client. 

We hadn't been concentrating on the page detailed here because it is not technically part of the App Center, at least it certainly won't feel like it for the user.

The improvements detailed here make the assumption that this will be the landing page for the app center, but no app store would have so many of the add-ons listed here. I think it's a mistake to mix promos, news stories, etc. alongside category and feature app tiles, before we're fully immersed in the app center itself.

To me, what is being described here is rather a higher-level SPLASH PAGE, that mostly serves marketing purposes, and from which users can get to the App Center. I'm not sure what the higher level is, but I believe it is ACI.

We can, of course, provide some an improved design for this page, but I think a discussion is needed or it can compromise our current design proposal.



--

169.body:
Hi Nihal and Dev,

First: our goal. 

Sinna and Shirley will help set up a VERY IMPORTANT meeting this Thursday or Friday. During that meeting, actual engineers who use the Cisco App Center will take our InVision link and play around while giving us feedback.

How great is that?

Now, there is work to be done, but rather than push the team in too many directions at once, here's my direction for how we should proceed.

#1. Align Nihal and Jonathan designs.
We've used J's designs for InVision, but you've also made some improvements to the UI. So, we need to bring the two in line. Before we fill in ANY GAPS, please make sure that the current screens we have are consistent in the following manner. 
• Global navigation - Let's use yours, Nihal.
• Banner section - We've been consistent with these, so don't change.
• Tabbed filters - We should keep J's approach, which really works nice in InVision, and Sinna did like it.
• Individual app tiles - We currently have consistency in the tiles' style. Four tiles per row works right now. Keep as is.
• Bundle tiles - I believe that we shouldn't mix up the app tiles with the bundle tiles. I think bundle should be one of the tabs, right after Popular, and that the content would filter to show bundles there.

#2. Welcome and Introduction
I discussed with Sinna my concern about how the we've been given some landing page requirements... but I think we shouldn't confuse the more marketing-focused landing page with the app center landing page itself. So... what we came up with was to have a two-step experience to welcome NEW users (after that, the messages don't come back). 
• Welcome Message - Upon first loading, the app center page would be taken over by a welcome message.
• Introductory Overlay - After user has dismissed the welcome message (or hits NEXT), an overlay appears that can point out the main features of the app center.
Some examples below:









#3. Unifying the UI for several types of experiences

So, in our wireframes we have a Search Results page. I believe we need to illustrate this, so we can show searching as part of the InVision interactive sequence.

Additionally, there are 2 other experiences that would produce a similar page (with slight differences). 


• Bundle Page - If I open a bundle tile, I should arrive at a Bundle page that lists the apps in the bundle. Different from the Search Results page, the Bundle page would need to have a short text introduction explaining the bundle.
• Category Page - Similar to Bundle page above, the Category page would need an introduction on top. I will explain later how I think users would arrive at the Category page, but I'll say now that I don't think you should get to it from the Landing page.

 



--

Tracker for cross-functional teams, new FemgineerTV (x2), jobs, and more



THE TRACKER BACKLOG—SUMMER 2016
In this mid-summer issue, we look at how cross-functional teams can best use Tracker, discuss an updated integration from Raygun, and learn how to follow a creative calling and recover from setbacks with two new episodes of FemgineerTV. Oh, and Tracker’s hiring!

TRACKER FOR CROSS-FUNCTIONAL TEAMS
The way you use Tracker and your experience with it varies greatly depending on your role and your team’s needs. This post outlines how cross-functional teams can best leverage Tracker to deliver quality products and maintain smooth operation.
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/community/tracker-blog/tracker-and-cross-functional-teams-where-do-you-fit-in
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4TYv2PhG89A

RAYGUN INTEGRATION
Tracker has been been integrated with Raygun for some time now, but they recently made a big update, and this guest post explains how to set it up. Raygun pulls detailed diagnostics on any errors affecting your users right down to the line of code, and automatically allocates them to a team’s story inside Tracker.
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/community/tracker-blog/use-raygun-and-pivotal-tracker-together-for-better-project-management

FEMGINEERTV
The latest episode looks at how to save yourself from a setback with InDinero’s Jessica Mah. And if you missed the previous episode about branching out on your own to follow a creative inspiration, with designer Jessice Hische, be sure to check it out.
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/community/femgineer-tv/
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/community/tracker-blog/prepare-strike-pursue-creative-calling
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/community/tracker-blog/how-to-rescue-yourself-from-a-risky-setback

LOOKING FOR A NEW JOB?
We’ve got some of those! The Tracker team is seeking a software engineer, mobile software engineer, and UX/product designer to join us in our office in beautiful downtown Denver. Visit our Jobs page for more info on these positions and on the sweet life at Team Tracker.
http://www.pivotaltracker.com/jobs/

SPRINGONE PLATFORM
Aug 1–4 | Las Vegas, NV
Tracker will be at the SpringOne Platform next week, which is bringing together the people, process, and tools for delivering and operating software services. Learn and share with the startups and enterprises leveraging modern Java with Spring connecting all the pieces of the modern software puzzle, including developers, operators, architects, data scientists, and executives.
https://springoneplatform.io/





875 Howard St. 5th Floor | San Francisco, CA 94103 US

Short description (can be used next to the app icon on the details page):

Ansible is a free-software platform for configuring and managing computers which combines multi-node software deployment, ad hoc task execution, and configuration management.

Longer description:

Ansible is a radically simple IT automation engine that automates cloud provisioning,configuration management, application deployment, intra-service orchestration, and many other IT needs.

Being designed for multi-tier deployments since day one, Ansible models your IT infrastructure by describing how all of your systems inter-relate, rather than just managing one system at a time.

It uses no agents and no additional custom security infrastructure, so it's easy to deploy - and most importantly, it uses a very simple language (YAML, in the form of Ansible Playbooks) that allow you to describe your automation jobs in a way that approaches plain English.

178.body:
Hi Nihal,

I actually went through the work you've done and have very specific feedback today about each of the pages.

1. Welcome Message Overlay
• Use the copy that is in the current Cisco App Center website instead of Lorem Ipsum (underneath the Welcome!).
• I would change the button from "Get Started" to "Continue."
• Spread the content out a bit instead of concentrating at top left.
• Also, once user presses "Continue" button, we should come to a screen that contains the same content as the one below, but instead of "The network for developers" it should say "Are you a developer?".


2. Quick Tutorial Overlay
I think we need to go more in the direction below instead of the little circle windows, which is a good concept, but too limiting for this interface.



• Let's make the overlay more transparent so we can see the whole page.
• Let's use dividing lines and some descriptive text to show:
• Controls allow you to search for apps and bundles or bookmark favorites.
• Banners will announce such things as new and featured apps and bundles.
• Tabs help you browse, organize, and filter available apps and bundles.
• Tiles highlight basic information about each app or bundle; click on any tile to access more details.

3. Landing Page: Default
The banners at the top should be to feature different apps/bundles or announce a new added app or bundle. So, a few changes:
• I currently see 2 Ansible mini-banners. We clearly only need one.
• We need some labeling that says "NEW" or "Featured App" or "Featured Bundle" for these banners.
• This is nit-picky but the first two banners are green, and I would vary the colors a bit.
In the control icons (top right) I would also add a Help icon to the right of the other 3.
Also, we need to start turning these tiles into actually showing the icons for the apps that exist in the current App Center. I have posted all the images in our documents on basecamp (D1 folder). I have ALSO added other app logo images that would be "realistic" (in the same folder). 

4. Landing Page: "Command Line" Category selected
• The "Command Line" tab looks too subtle when shown selected in gray. I would invert the colors here so it looks blue, no?
• Let's show the amount of tiles go down in this page, which would be more realistic. I would not show a page FULL of apps (my preference is just 7-9, no more). 

5. Landing Page: Search
Ok! Leave as is, but whatever has been said before applies here, too.

6. Search Results: List View
I like most of this page, especially the list view for Apps (by the way, change "App Results" to just "Apps"). 
• Make less work for yourself, just show 4 results, not 8. We'll need to move to make the content realistic, so the more apps you list, more work for us.
• "Results for" is too little for me. This is technically the "title" of this page, which is a list of whatever the user has searched for.
• Not sure that the tag approach works ("Cloud Computing" as a tag, which can be taken out). For now, let's just show the term here that the person has searched for, but not within a tag.
• Where you have a list of Platforms 1-6, I would assume that this section is for filters (even though right now Platforms are the only filter category now). So, I'd more those filters a bit lower, give them the title "Platforms" and then list the actual 6 platforms shown in the current site, alongside checkboxes (so user could filter by clicking on 2+ platforms at once). 

7. Search Results: Tile View
I'm not sure we actually need this view. I've thought about it and let's take it out for now. I don't want to give users an option to change from list to tile view. The list view here really benefits the search results page.

8. Landing Page: Bundles
• To me, we need to work on the tiles for bundles. It's strange to me that bundles, which are collections of apps, are smaller tiles than the app tiles. I would make them larger instead. Additionally, in this larger bundle tiles, you could show some of the logos of the apps contained in the bundle. 
• Also, the information inside the bundle tiles is strange. I don't believe these bundles will have more than 4 to 9 apps inside, not 30+. 
• I would not say that the total number of bundles here would be very high to start. Again, maybe 10 but no more.

9. Bundle Page
• I like the approach to the banner... but I really do think that the layout we need is similar to the list approach that you see in the search page. Will you trust me on this? The main reason why is that when I look at a bundle, I might really want to read a description of each app inside it, and that list view allows for that.
• Oh, and we need a DOWNLOAD ALL button inside the banner (yes, do keep the banner even when using the list view approach).

10. Category Page
I will give you, Nihal, this one. I think it should be like the one you made for Bundled Kit Title, with a banner on top, and a tiled view below. In the case of the Category page, the user is not likely to not need a list view. What do you think?



--

Hi offshore team,

I'm writing because I haven't had a chance to come back to writing some notes for this project and I really need to call it a night. However, the thought occurred to me that the improvements that need to be made to the flow we have (including both Nihal's and Jonathan's screens) are mostly inconsistencies or gaps that could be picked up by a QA review.

Could we focus on that today? 

Also, quick note for Nihal that I still believe the Bundled Kit page should be in the list view. I do not like having a 2-column list layout for Bundled Kits. You can try to convince me otherwise, but my reasoning is that I need to easily track which apps from the bundle I've downloaded, and which ones I have not. There should be individual download buttons for each app, in addition to the download all button. 

Thanks,
Andrés



--

206.body:
We need to work to create a set of very specific standards for the images that we can use for various apps

As it has been brought to our attention, developers currently have the ability to upload their own graphics/images for a given app.  As a result, this certainly presents a set of challenges, and really could have a negative effect on the overall look of the App Center (they fear). Given this, it makes it increasingly important to have a very specific requirement for the size/quality of graphics that we allow developers to upload.

It may be that we keep the optimal size/quality for a company's logo and all a developer would do is simply choose his/her logo out of the library we have available to them.. This will need a little further discussion.

We may need to tighten up the amount of white space on the page a bit (they mentioned this specifically for the app detail page, below the banner)

It was asserted that developers will not want to go through a walkthrough upon arriving on the App Center for the first time, so it seems that a walkthrough may be low on our priority list (I don't think we need to focus our efforts on this too much at the moment)

They said that the home page appears to be missing a few items that we need to integrate in some way (there could be up to 4-5 sections):

1.)  Marketing content  (currently an exceedingly oversized banner that takes up much of the page)

2.) Featured  ( We have already done this, but it seems they have something very specific in mind for how this should appear on the page) 

3.) A section for signing up, as a developer (Are you able to sign up as any other user?)

It was asked that we create an additional version of the reviews page, however without bar graph visualization, or avatars for users  (I have created this)
     
 Content to be included within each review:


• Title
• The first name of person it was submitted by
• Number of stars 
• The description 






--
